repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body:
Is this whole `hasattr` dance really needed? Why wouldn't a normal attribute access work?
(BTW, `getattr()`with default is more efficient than `hasattr()` plus an attribute lookup.)
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -330,6 +330,9 @@ def __init__(self, file, filename, parent_scanner=None,
         self.indentation_char = None
         self.bracket_nesting_level = 0
         self.async_enabled = 0
+        if parent_scanner and hasattr(parent_scanner, 'async_enabled') and \
+            parent_scanner.async_enabled:

comment_data.body: I think the test file name is too broad for just this test. I'd say it can just go into `tests/run/fstring.pyx`, since that's what it really tests.
Like I saw from Travis's tests not every parent scaner has attribute "async_enabled" (like I undeerstood ppoblem was in some anaconda's builds), about other - ok.

comment_data.body:
ok, I was confused by
https://github.com/cython/cython/issues/2877#issuecomment-472551784

P.S.
Sorry for delay, I stuck on reproducing  the last errors from Travis, on my computer I haven't this (but seems like I have found how to reproduce it)

Compilation turns the `async_enabled` attribute into an internal, compiled attribute (since it's declared as a `cdef` attribute). You can make it `cdef readonly` in `Scanning.pxd` to make it available as a read-only Python property, and then just copy its value over from the `parent_scanner`, instead of calling `enter_async()`.

comment_data.body: Could you remove the `getattr()`, please? It should now work with normal attribute access. If not, then that is something to fix, not to work around.
